description: This course is intended to introduce students to the field of engineering. It will expose students to the engineering disciplines through hands-on laboratory experiences. In addition, the course will provide tutorials on how to use important software packages as well as a "Professional Preparation" module through studies of communication (writing and speaking skills), ethics, leadership and teamwork. This course is ideal for any freshman interested in exploring the possibility of studying engineering at Penn. The course counts as as a engineering requirement in SEAS.
name: INTRO TO ENGINEERING

values.comments:
This course is intended to introduce students to the field of engineering. It exposes students to the engineering disciplines through hands-on laboratory experiences. In addition, the course provides tutorials on how to use important software packages as well as a "Professional Preparation" module through studies of communication (writing and speaking skills), ethics, leadership and teamwork.

Students generally found this course to be helpful and felt that they learned a lot from it. They described it as “interesting and useful” and “a nice experience.” Many students reported really enjoying the chance to talk to Penn Engineering alumni about their respective experiences as SEAS students.

Professor Pope was regarded by many students as “a very good teacher,” but most students did not find him very accessible.

This course is usually taken by freshman engineering students who are undecided on which major they want to pursue. Students generally concurred that “sampling of projects from each [engineering] discipline” really helped them decide which major was the best fit for them. Although many felt that the “grading was really tough,” students described this course as “important…for people who are not sure what type of engineering they want to major in.”
